newsitem.title: GERMANY: German copper recycling firm sees higher 97 output.
newsitem.headline: German copper recycling firm sees higher 97 output.

text.p: German copper producer Huettenwerke Kayser AG (HK) expects to increase output in 1977 to meet buoyant demand, a company spokesman said on Friday.
"We're confident we will be able to produce at full capacity...large parts of the output are already committed to customers via long-term contracts and the rest will also be easily placed," he said.
"We have targeted 170,000-175,000 tonnes of cathode production now that our investment programme has been completed."
HK, which works solely on the basis of secondary copper, produced 166,000 tonnes of cathodes in 1996.
The spokesman said high copper prices would encourage scrap sellers to bring out supplies.

Cash London Metals Exchange (LME) prices, converted into marks on the basis of the daily Frankfurt currency fixing, were around 4,000 marks a tonne on average in the first quarter of 1997 compared with a 1996 average of 3,453 marks.
The HK spokesman said the market had overcome a crisis in the summer of last year when the Sumitomo copper debacle and weak demand meant prices plummeted and scrap was scarce.
The company in a statement issued preliminary figures for 1996, ahead of a shareholders meeting on July 1.
It showed sales totalling 1.035 million marks were only slightly below 1.060 million in 1995.
Production in 1966 was 44,000 tonnes higher than in 1995 and accounted for 25 percent of Germany's refined copper output.
